div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin May 31st 1915
div1.p: I’m so anxious to hear from you after Curtin’s farewell visit. He might have told a lot of things you know. Oh, I’m not worrying about that_ only curious. For twelve days now the postal service hasn’t been working as far as we’re concerned and I’ve received no letters at all.

A great deal of fighting has been going on of late and our work has been so heavy that I’ve found no time to write. We’ve broken all records
for American Ambulance sections and the officers here are seemingly very well pleased with our work. In fact we have been recommended for mention in the Order of the Day. What do you know about that Ma Chere Mademoiselle Marcelle?

By the way. Do you still entertain a desire to work up front or are you satisfied at Neuilly? I ask, for I understand that nurses would be welcomed here and God knows they are terribly
needed. If you wish I will go more carefully into the matter for you. The town is delightful and I’m sure you would enjoy the river and above all the gardens. Then too your work would give you a feeling of satisfaction; a realization that you were helping France every minute. Of course there is one draw back and that is that you wouldn’t be so very comfortable and then again there are the bombardments which might prove
more or less annoying. Still, while thirty-one people were killed and fifty wounded in a short bombardment four days ago I nevertheless think that they are slowing up. They certainly aren’t as bad as they used to be. Besides in a hospital you are comparatively safe.

That reminds me. I got hit by shrapnel the other day but didn’t get hurt much. I was up at the most advanced Poste de Secours, next to a battery when the
Germans began shooting shrapnel at the artillery position. The blooming things were zizz-zizz zizz--ker-bang ing all over the place and one shell went thru [sic] a tree ten feet off. The first thing I knew was that something poked me a jab in the back over my kidneys and I staggered a bit from the shock. A lieutenant asked me if I was wounded and came over to me. It was a huge joke for I reached around and pulled out a bit of the shrapnel
casing that hadn’t gone into me at all. It just went thru [sic] my uniform and when it encountered my tough hide couldn’t go any further. All I received was a bloody bruise that’s nearly well now. Another fellow was with me and his car was quite badly cut up by the same shell.

I hate to see these bombardments. It isn’t bad being under fire out where the fighting is going on, for the thing is part of the game and the atmosphere
is entirely military, but here in town where no one is getting back at the Boches it seems out of place. One may buy cakes from a woman in the morning and haul her out a bloody mess in the afternoon. The other day a fellow named Dunning and I had the pleasant job of breaking open a store window and getting out three hideous looking corpses. The blood had run from the room under the door to the sidewalk and was in a great pool outside. Two
women and a soldier were lying in the awkward postures of those suddenly killed. All of the face of one woman was shot away save an eye and that looked up at us. As we picked her up her combs fell out and her bloody hair fell backward. It was terrible.
When the mail finally comes I’m sure I will have the pleasure of finding a letter from you.
